description: A thin aluminum plate, usually sitting at the bottom of a magazine.  Can be attached to aluminum STANAG magazine bodies to turn them into usable magazines.

variants.description: A thin aluminum plate with a curved edge.  When installed, prevents the magazine spring from falling out of the magazine.  Can be installed onto a relevant magazine body in order to make it a usable magazine.  <variant:steel>

//weight: estimated based on the weight of the PMAG baseplate

//notes: the base plate is said to be 69 mm in length
description: A thin plastic plate, usually sitting at the bottom of a magazine. Can be attached to PMAG magazine bodies to turn them into usable magazines.

variants.description: A thin plastic plate with curved edges.  When installed, prevents the magazine spring from falling out of the magazine.  Can be installed onto a relevant magazine body in order to make it a usable magazine.  <variant:black>

//weight: we assume that the value is given per 5 plates in the package

description: A plastic loop skewed to one side, usually sitting at the bottom of a magazine.  Can be attached to PMAG magazine bodies to turn them into usable magazines with a hook to hang them off carabiners with.

variants.description: A plastic loop with curved edges and skewed to one side.  Can be attached to PMAG magazines to allow the resulting usable magazines to hang off carabiners and other hooks.  Note: PMAG-specific plates do not fit conventional STANAG magazines.  <variant:black>

//weight: two sources state roughly the same value between two different models of ranger plates: 52 g / 3 = 17.33 g, or 0.6 oz = 17.01 g
even though this references two different models, we assume the difference between the two is negligible, and thus use the latter value for all ranger plates
//price: we assume the price is for three pieces

description: A plastic loop skewed to one side, usually sitting at the bottom of a magazine.  Can be attached to STANAG magazine bodies to turn them into usable magazines with a hook to hang them off carabiners with.

variants.description: A plastic loop with curved edges and skewed to one side.  Can be attached to conventional STANAG magazines to allow the resulting usable magazines to hang off carabiners and other hooks.  Note: STANAG-specific plates do not fit PMAGs or other types of 5.56mm magazines.  <variant:black>

//weight: presuming the same weight as the PMAG ranger plate
//price: we assume the price is for three pieces

//notes: there is a lot more colors of the plate, but we only implement the black one for the sake of simplicity for now
advertised as +5 on 30-round magazines, +6 on 40-round magazines
according to The Mag Shack, the extension is compatible with the 20-, 30-, and 40-round PMAGs, but not 10-rounders
it's also not compatible with the .300 Blackout-exclusive PMAGs
description: A thick aluminum cup with the manufacturer's logo stamped on the side.  Can be attached to PMAG magazine bodies to turn them into usable magazines with capacity extended.  30-round magazines get 5 extra rounds, while 40-round ones get 6.
